titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. This morning, Mr: Plincke, my Land lord, called upon me, and informed me that on Saturday last he had concluded his contract for the sale of the house, and came now from the Minister of the interior to enquire whether it would be convenient for the tenants to quit the house on the first day of July Old-Stile; that being the time when it would be wanted; as at that time the lease of the house in the stead of which this one was purchased, would expire— I desired Mr: Plincke to present my compliments to the Minister of the interior, and inform him that unless he sent me a Police Officer to turn me out, I could not engage to go at so short notice. I reminded him of the lease which I had untill the first of June of next year; and that I had sent to him two months ago when there had already been some talk about the sale of the house, and when I had an opportunity of engaging another— That he had then told me the contract was broken off, and that the house would not be sold— He admitted the fact and had no very good apology to offer for himself— He asked whether he might answer that I would take the subject into consideration— I told him that if he had sold the house I did not know that I had any thing more to discuss with him about it. That I was ready and had been from the first of the month to pay him the half-year’s Rent in advance— That to accommodate the service of the Emperor I would quit the house as soon as possible; but that I claimed the benefit of whatever the laws of the Country would allow me upon my lease— He said he did not suppose it would be expected that we should go out; and that they had only sent to enquire whether it would be convenient. As however it is necessary to provide as soon as possible for this contingency, I sent Waldstein immediately to Count Tatischeff, the owner of the house I had seen in April on the St: Petersburg or Apothecary’s island, and which is still untenanted— From the answer he brought I sent to engage the house for the remainder of the Summer; four months from the 1st: of July Old-Stile— Captain Welsh was here with Mr: Woodward— He was going to Cronstadt, immediately; to sail with the Palafox to-morrow— Captain Vibberts of the Experiment also called, intending to sail to-morrow— I gave them both letters— Mr: David was here with Mr Blodget who brought me letters from Mr Ewing in Philadelphia, and Mr Lewis in London— I dined at Mr Laval’s in the Country; with a company of about forty persons, Ladies and Gentlemen— The Ambassador and most of the diplomatic corps were there— I had conversation at table with Mr: Rayneval who told me something of a grant of lands in America to his uncle. He will speak with me further about it. Walked round the gardens with Mr Prevost— I also walk’d the principal part of the way home, and in the Summer Gardens.

2. There was a heavy thunder-shower between two and three o’clock this morning, after which I had no sleep.— Mr: Harris was here, and Mr: Plummer came and introduced to me his brother who has just arrived— The heat of the weather continued, and disqualifies me almost entirely for any serious occupation— I received a new Packet of American Newspapers but none of them later than March— Mr: Navarro likewise paid me a morning visit— Mrs Adams went out and looked at the House which I have concluded to take upon the island— There was a second heavy shower between 7 and 8 this Evening; after which the wind came to the Eastward, and the weather became cooler.

3. Mrs: Adams was very unwell this morning— I went out to the Country house which I am about to take for the remainder of the Summer Months; and called at Count Tolstoy’s but did not fine him at home— Returning I looked over a house on the Quay of the Neva, which is to be let; but found it would not suit my purpose— Mr: Fisher and Mr: Blodget called on me— The morning passed away, and I had done nothing— After dinner I walked in the Summer Gardens— Coming home I met Mr: Jones, and afterwards General Pardo, with whom I had some Conversation upon Spanish affairs— I found Mr: Harris at our house when I returned— Count Romanzoff sent me a small packet from Mr: Russell, brought by a Courier from Paris.—

4. Anniversary of American Independence— A day, which Americans are accustomed to celebrate with many festivities, at home and abroad— But the toasting and roasting of it in numerous parties of very mixed company, are so little suited to my taste that I have generally avoided this celebration whenever I conveniently could— The party Spirit and the intemperance which prevail on these occasions have rendered them disagreeable to me, and I prefer spending the day with my family— I have done so this day. Mr: Fisher called on me in the morning, and I went with him to one of the sheeting and linen warehouses near the exchange where I selected two pieces of linen to be sent to my Mother and my Sister— After an Evening walk in the Summer Gardens, I went with the Ladies and Mr Gray, and paid a visit to the Chevalier Bezzera and his Lady— We found Mr Navarro there— My Son John is if it please God this day eight years old— Charles 3 f. 1. i.

5. I went this morning again with Mrs: Adams to the linen shop where I had been yesterday with Mr Fisher— After dinner we went and looked over a house in town that is to be let— It is that where the Duke de Mondragone resided when I first arrived here— A good house for the Summer, with a large Garden, but excessively cold in Winter, and out of repair— We then went to the House which I have engaged on the island— I walked home from the Summer-Garden Bridge— Mr: Fisher and Mr: Blodget were with us untill near Midnight.

6. Early this morning I received a packet from Mr: Harris, brought by Captain Bainbridge who arrived last Evening— It contained a letter from Mrs Johnson enclosing one for Catherine, and a despatch from the department of State, consisting entirely of duplicates— The Commission for me as an associate Justice of the Supreme Court U.S.— Letter of Leave to the Emperor, and letter from the Secretary of State R. Smith—of 26. February— Mr: Raimbert made me a long visit before Breakfast— Mr Harris, with his nephew and Captain Bainbridge immediately after—and Mr: Patterson, who is going down to Cronstadt and to England— With much difficulty I finished a letter for the Secretary of State, but not in Season to send by Mr Patterson— We sent off a large boat-load of furniture to the house we have taken upon the island, where I went with the Ladies and Charles in the Evening.— I walked home, after a turn in the Summer-Gardens.

7. Long visit from Mr: Boucher, early this morning— He mentioned to me a Traité de la Police, by De la Marre in three volumes folio, which he says contains much excellent information concerning the circulation of Air, in populous Cities— Captain Silsbee was here, and I gave him a despatch and letter to be sent by the Herald— Mr. Smith, Mrs C. Miller’s brother reached here at last, after a year’s detention by a Danish Capture—he also paid me a visit— Captain Bainbridge, Mr: Harris and his Nephew, Messrs: Hollins, Moses, Jones, Fisher, David, and Wallis, dined with us— Mr: Smith and Mr: Gray were on a party at Czarsko Zelo, and Mr Everett dined abroad— Mr. and Madame Bezzera and Mr Navarro pass’d an hour or two with us of the Evening— I walked an hour shortly before Midnight. Read two Synodial Discourses of Massillon and Sections 29. 30. of Robinson’s life of Christ.— Almost the whole of this day again was lost.

8. I was up this morning earlier than four O’Clock— After Breakfast I had visits from Mr: Plummer with a Captain Bowers from Providence, and from Mr: B. Cramer, who came on Account of Mr Hazard— He is still detained at Cronstadt, waiting for his Passport to come to St: Petersburg, and supposing that his Commission as Consul at Archangel would enable him to come sooner, he desired Mr: Cramer, to apply to me for it. I gave it to him accordingly— I went out to the house we are to live in, this morning, and arranged some of the Books we had sent out— Mr Jones dined with us— Mr: Everett and Mr Gray dined abroad— Went out to the house again after dinner, with the Ladies— Mr: Jones also went with us.— I walked home— The distance is seven Wersts; a little short of five English Miles.

9. Captain Peert of the Hope a vessel of Mr Samuel Gray’s arrived at from Salem, came this morning with Captain Harris, and brought me a letter of 10. April from my father— We sent out this afternoon a second Boat-load of furniture to the Island— It suffered by the rain— In the Evening I went to the French Theatre, and saw La Jeunesse de Henry 5, a miserable travesti from Shakespear’s Play; and L’Entrepreneur dans l’Embarras an Opera— Music of Cimarosa—

10. A storm of wind and rain which continued almost the whole of this day somewhat impeded our preparations for removing.— I wrote a Note to Count Romanzoff requesting a Courier’s Passport for Mr Everett who is going to Stockholm, intending to travel some time longer before he returns to America— I went with him also to Count Stedingk’s, whom we did not find at home— Mr: Moses called upon me for a Passport— Mr Jones and he are going to the Fair of Makarieff, and left the City this afternoon— I went with Mrs: Adams after dinner to the house on the Island, and unpacked the trunks of books and papers that I had sent out yesterday— Mr Fisher and Mr: Blodget spent an hour with us at the close of the Evening. As I was returning home I met the Chevalier Brancia who walked with me from the Bridge to the Admiralty Corner.

11. We had fixed upon this day for our removal to the house we had taken on the Apothecaries Island, four Wersts or 2 3/4 Miles from the Summer Garden Gate— I was up at 6 in the morning, and after reading my usual portion, and writing about an hour employed the remainder of the day in removing— I came out before dinner with Catherine and Charles in the Carriage, and brought a trunk with my most valuable papers—returned to dine and in the Evening we all came out— I walked and found the distance 4 3/4 miles or 7 Wersts.
The day was fine, and we sent out the last Boat-load of our furniture— We had just got all the Articles safe into the house when it began to rain— We got up our iron bed-stead, just in time for the Night— Mr: Everett, who had dined abroad, and who now leaves us came out to see us in the Evening.— I am this day forty-four years of age.

12. I went into the City this morning and called upon Count Lüxbourg, but did not find him at home. I then went to Count Stedingk’s, whom I found just ready to dress, going to take leave of the Emperor— The vessel in which he is to return to Sweden, having arrived— Count St. Julien was with him, and went out as I went in. I asked him for a Courier’s Passport for Mr Everett which he promised to give me— He expects to go himself in eight or ten days— I found the house where we late resided shut up, and called upon the Chevalier Bezerra, the Portuguese Minister— Count St: Julien was there also—and Mr Navarro— I returned home with Mr Everett and Mr Gray to dinner— In the Evening we had a visit from Commodore Bainbridge and Mr Fisher.

13. Mr: Hazard and Mr: Smith of Boston came to see me this morning— Mr: Hazard came up only last Evening from Cronstadt— I continued to be occupied almost the whole morning in arranging my Cabinet and Library.— Mr Everett did not come out to dinner. I walked in the Evening in Count Stroganoff’s Garden, and examined what is called the tomb of Homer— On returning I met Mr: Harris who had been to see us, and who turned back and returned with me.— Our situation is very pleasant on the Banks of the Great Nevka river, in sight of the Emperor’s Palace at Kammenoi-ostroff, and nearly opposite Count Stroganoff’s Garden— From my Cabinet windows I see all the boats passing up and down the river, and am as quiet and undisturbed, as if it were an hermitage a hundred miles from the City.

14. Mr Fisher, Mr Blodget and Mr Smith of Boston dined and spent the Evening with us— Mr Navarro also came out in the Evening— I employed the morning in writing; and I read two Synodial discourses of Massillon and two Sections of Robinson’s character of Christ—concluding the third volume— My occupation, my Company, and the weather prevented me the whole day from my usual exercise of walking.

15. I was unwell last Night, and up this morning at 4. O’Clock— Continued unwell the whole day, but went to a diplomatic dinner at Count Romanzoff’s. It was to take leave of Count Stedingk, and a dinner of reception for the Chevalier Bezerra— I told the Chancellor that in a few days I should ask an interview with him to present to him Mr: Hazard who is appointed by the Government of the United States, Consul at Archangel— He said that to save me the trouble of writing he would propose that it should be on Wednesday at 11. O’Clock in the Morning, to which I agreed— I had some conversation with the French Ambassador— He asked me how our affairs stood with England— I told him I thought it probable that his Government would make our Peace with England— How?— By not keeping their word— They had promised the repeal of the Berlin and Milan decrees, and had not kept their promise— [“]Oh! but you must seize two or three English vessels, and then I will promise you, that you may come freely to France and will never be troubled, with the Berlin and Milan decrees— Only you must not bring English Merchandize to us.— Americans will not bring you any English Merchandize except when you insist upon having it— But you give so many licences for trading with England, that there is no temptation of profit to carry any English Goods to you”— “No— No—we do not give any more licences”— Ay! Ay! My spies (He had said in a joke that his spies had not informed him that I had moved into his neighbourhood) my spies, give me quite different information!— “Well; if we get English Merchandize it is only to burn it— Yes; and you have burnt so much that now you are obliged to send for more for your own use— All this was said on both sides in a sort of banter, half jest, half earnest— Blome was standing by, and enjoyed it very much.— I had forgotten to go with the mourning crepe— But there were several others in the same predicament to keep me in Countenance— After dinner, I called at Mr Fishers and left a letter for the Secretary of State and a Message for Mr Hazard— After returning home I walked in Count Stroganoff’s Garden— Commodore Bainbridge, Mr: Harris and his Nephew, and the two Mr Plummer’s spent the Evening with us— Mr Everett was also here, and agreed at Mr Harris’s desire to postpone his departure untill Wednesday.

16. Mr: Hazard called upon me this morning, and informed me that he should be ready to pay his visit to Count Romanzoff to-morrow morning— I was employed untill near dinner time, in settling the Accounts of the last Month— In the Evening, I walked down the river’s side to the Bridge which goes over towards Wyburg— Cross’d it and walk’d up on the opposite Bank to Count Stroganoff’s gate—through his Garden, and over the Kamminoi ostroff Bridges home— The distance is about ten Wersts; or seven Miles— I found the Chevalier and Madam Bezerra when I reached home— They were upon an Evening visit to the Ladies— Count Maistre sent me this day his manuscript translation of Plutarch’s Treatise on the delays of Divine Justice.— I read the Preface, and a small part of the work itself.

17. On rising this morning I received from Count Romanzoff, a note informing me that having just received an account of the death of his brother Michael, he was under the necessity of requesting me with the Consul of the United States for Archangel, to postpone for a few days our visit to him, and that he would give me further notice of the day when he could receive us.—
I had agreed to call upon Mr Hazard at his lodgings at 11. O’Clock; but Captain Kennedy and afterwards Mr: Montreal came, and detained me at home untill 12. I then went into the City and called upon Mr Hazard, informing him that our visit to Count Romanzoff must for a few days be postponed— I saw at Rea’s Hotel Captain Leach and Mr Webb who conversed with respecting their vessels From thence I went to Mr: Harris’s house, into which he has lately moved, and spoke to him of the certificate which Captain Leach had asked of him, and which he had scrupled to give—but I found it was a question merely with regard to its form— He gave me some Boston papers to the 16th: of May— I next went to the lodgings of Messrs: Everett and Gray, where I found some letters and newspapers brought by Captain Marchant who arrived yesterday and of which I had heard at Rea’s— The letters were merely duplicates.— Mr Everett was on the point of departure; on his journey to Sweden— I took leave of him, and he left the City about 2.— After a visit to the shops I returned home— After dinner I walked in Count Stroganoff’s gardens, and took Charles with me— On returning home I found Mr Fisher and Mr Roberts at the house— Mr Roberts is the same gentleman who was here last Summer and has just arrived from Baltimore— He brought a letter to my wife, from her sister Mrs Buchanan.

18. Mr Smith of Boston was here this morning with Mr Fenno of New-York— And afterwards Mr Harris with Mr Calhoun of Philadelphia— This Gentleman arrived yesterday, after a passage of 39 days from the Capes of Delaware to Cronstadt— The shortest I have known— He brought me a letter of Introduction from Mr: Pierce Butler, dated 4. June at Philadelphia—with two Packets from the Department of State, containing a file of the National Intelligencer to 1. June. but no letters— He says that Mr. Dallas wrote to the Secretary of State mentioning the opportunity to write, but Mr Monroe answered that he expected I should be upon my passage home.— I dined at the French Ambassador’s, with a Company of about twenty persons; mostly of the corps diplomatique— Mr Tettard told me that he should go to-morrow Morning as a Courier for Paris; and offered to take any letters for me; but I have been so absorbed in the multitude of American Newspapers that I found no time to write.— I took an Evening walk in Count Stroganoff’s Gardens.

19. I had a restless and uneasy Night— Sleepless untill 4. in the Morning; and then I slept untill past ten— Mr Montréal had been waiting below, two full hours when I rose— The continual day-light makes regular repose to me altogether impossible, and I find my health affected by the relaxation of summer— Mr Woodward was here and gave an explanation somewhat different from that of Mr Montréal, of one of the drafts by Messrs: Raimbert upon the House of Bainbridge and Brown, on Account of Mr: W. Gray.— The transaction was in the first instance effected partly without my knowledge and partly against my advice— The parties now do not agree in their story— This irregularity shews how difficult it is to keep a perfect order in the complicated business of a great merchant.— Captain Boit of the Cordelia called upon me. He arrived the day before yesterday. He brought me a letter of Introduction from my father, and a collection of U.S. Coins and three sets of my lectures from my brother— He gave several other letters for us, to Mr: Sparrow at Cronstadt to have them sent more expeditiously, but I did not receive them— The whole of the Morning, except while engaged with these visitors, I again spent in looking over the American Newspapers— After dinner I took a long walk on the Kammenoi-Ostroff— After I returned home Mr Fisher came in with Captain Lloyd Jones of the Lion. They staid untill between 11 and midnight.

20. Lost entirely the Night’s rest— Between two and three in the Morning, I changed the Bed-chamber for the room below; but without getting any sleep— As the Sun rises soon after 3. in the Morning, I employed the time in reading, and finished Mr Huskisson’s pamphlet, on the depretiation of English Bank Paper. About 9. in the Morning, I took a warm Bath— I was disqualified for writing, and the morning was taken up almost wholly by visitors— Mr: Montreal and Mr Woodward were both again here.— And Mr Plummer also came with Captain Lovett, and Mr: George Thorndike— Captain Lovett has just arrived and brought me letters— One from my dear Mother of 15. May—the latest that I have yet received from my family.— Mr: Fisher too was here with Mr: Tatem, Supercargo of the African, a ship which was lost between Port-Baltic and Reval last November— He has got involved in law-suits at Revel, and wants assistance to get extricated from them— Mr Smith dined in the City— After dinner, I rode around the islands, and returned over the Bridge from the Wisburg side— Walking from the Bridge home— Mr Harris spent an hour of the Evening with us— He is under great concern on account of the great number of American vessels arrived here and their prospects of unprofitable voyages— I received a Notice of a Te Deum to be sung to-morrow at the Tauridan Palace for a victory over the Turks.

21. The Notice for a Te Deum, fixed the time at half past eleven in the Morning— I rose later than usual owing to the broken rest of the two preceding Nights— I attended at the Tauridan Palace at the time appointed; but we waited there nearly two hours before the ceremony began— Count Stedingk and his Secretaries took leave of the Empress Mother, and her younger children— Mr: Bezerra was presented to them— Baron Blome invited me to dine with him this day— I was engaged at home— He asked me for the day after to-morrow, which I accepted.— The Emperor and Empress appeared well— It was three O’Clock before we could return home— Mr: Fisher dined with us.
After dinner we went up the river with the Ladies, in a boat; untill we came to the Gulph of Cronstadt— We were there hailed from a Custom-house guard, and returned home.— Mr: Fisher left us near Midnight.

22. took a cold Bath this Morning.— Captain Hovey and Captain Davis, Masters of two vessels of Mr: Gray, and his son William came and asked my advice with respect to their best mode of proceeding, which I gave them— I went into the City—visited Count Stedingk but he was not at home— Mr: and Madam Bezerra—they promised to dine with us on Wednesday— Mr Navarro too— He told me how kindly Count Romanzoff had treated him on his taking leave, and presenting Mr Bezerra, and shewed me the Box given him in the Emperor’s name— A gold box, with the cypher A— in diamond’s, surrounded by two rows of diamonds, and four large ones at the four Corners— He considers it, and the Count assured him that it was intended as a great and peculiar distinction—the cypher, and the size of the diamonds being unusual to a mere chargé des Affairs;— he is very much gratified with it, and certainly very deserving of it— I visited also Mr Labouchère, who has with him a Mr Bethman of Frankfort. I received all the letters for which I have been several days waiting.— Came home quite late to dinner— In the Evening I was at Mr Laval’s, where I found a numerous Company of Ladies and Gentlemen—home about 11. at Night.

23. Captain Stanwood of the Bellona came and brought letters from Mrs Johnson, to Catherine and myself; but they were of no later date than 1. March. I went into the City, and visited Count Lüxbourg, Baron Schladen, Chevalier Brancia, General Watzdorf, Mr: Krehmer and Mr Harris— With General Watzdorf and Count Lüxbourg I had much conversation; but there appears to be nothing of material importance occurring.— Dined at Baron Blome’s— Count St: Julien, Generals Pardo and Watzdorf, Chevaliers Bezerra and Navarro, Mr Laval, Count Bose, and some other company were present— Pardo told us with much pleasure of his having once forgotten an invitation to dinner at the Chancellor’s, and being reminded of it the same Evening at the Play— So he wrote a Card of excuse, and dated it the day before— But he said the Chancellor had never forgiven him, and if they had both been sovereigns would have declared War against him for it.— I had some Conversation with Blome, who says the Emperor Napoleon is going to Spain— After dinner I took a long walk on Kammenoi-Ostroff, and heard the musical band of the Chevalier Gardes practising— They do so every fair Evening in the open Air— There are about twenty-five of them— Clarinetts Horns and Drums— The music is charming— I lingered a full half hour on the river’s Banks to hear it. My wife has been quite unwell the greatest part of this day— She is approaching the time of her Confinement. May the Mercy of God, grant her a safe and joyful deliverance!

24. I rose this morning at a suitable hour— Between 6 and 7. O’Clock— A rare case since our removal into the Country— I had hoped that my hours of rising would have been more regular here than in the City; but from various causes have been totally disappointed— It has proved exactly the reverse. And I have consequently lost more than usual of my time— The consequence of this days regularity was that I wrote more than I have done any other day since our settlement here— Mr: Montreal was here this morning, and Mr Willing and Mr: Hall afterwards—the Chevalier Bezerra, and his Lady, Generals Pardo and Watzdorf, Chevaliers Navarro, Krabbe and Brancia, and Count Lüxbourg, dined with us— I had invited Baron Schladen and Mr Jouffroy— Count Maistre, Baron Blome, Mr Laval, Count Bose, Mr Krehmer and Mr Harris, all of whom were engaged or failed to come— Baron Blome and Mr Laval came after dinner— It was about 10 at Night before all the Company was gone, so that I did not walk— I received a note from Count Romanzoff, appointing eleven O’Clock to-morrow Morning, to see Mr Hazard and me at his house in the Country— I wrote a Note to Mr Hazard to be sent him early to-morrow morning.

25. I was waked about 2. O’Clock this morning, and from that time untill seven had no repose— I then slept between one and two hours longer— The weather, the unceasing day-light; a disordered stomach, and nervous agitations arising from the pressure of many deep anxieties upon my mind, all contribute to break my rest, depress my Spirits, and dissipate my time— When shall I recover even my ordinary assiduity?— Mr Montreal was here this morning, and brought some samples of Cambricks— Mr Hazard came as I had requested at half past ten— I went and introduced him at Count Romanzoff’s— He had taken with him his Commission, and a French Translation of it, but the Count did not look at them. He said he thought it would be sufficient for me to write him a note, mentioning the appointment, and the necessary document would be expedited, he believed from the Department of foreign Affairs—certainly not from the Chancellor’s Office— But as Mr Borel was at the head of the Department of the Consulates, if there were any other formalities necessary, he would send him to me to give me notice of them— For between you and me said the Count there can happen nothing but what will be rightly done— As Mr Hazard speaks scarcely any French, and the Count no English, he did not hold much conversation with him— He said turning to me, “Je crois que nous allons vous enlever le Comte Pahlen, mais ce sera pour le remplacement
Then laughing he added that it seemed to be a kind of destiny for Count Pahlen to visit all the Sovereigns of America, and if another such a power should arise in that Hemisphere, he did not know but that they should charge him with commencing the diplomatic relations of Russia with it— But Count Pahlen himself seemed to be much afraid of this mission to Brezil, for he had accepted it on the condition, or with the earnest sollicitation that it might be limited to two years— The Emperor had read his letter; and had been diverted at his concern— It was however determined in the course of two years to provide some place for him here at home, and so the commission would be sent him according to his own inclination.— And hereafter he was persuaded the Count would thank him for having given him the means of becoming so extensively acquainted with both the American Continents— As to such places as Cassel, or Stutgard, what could a Russian get by an appointment to them— It was easy to visit them, and great numbers did visit them without having diplomatic missions— But Count Pahlen on his return will have seen, what scarcely any Russian can have seen, and none to the same advantage— I said I hoped he would at least have occasion to remember the Country with pleasure— He said that with regard to our part of it he certainly would; as all his letters very fully testified— They were strongly expressive of his satisfaction with his situation there.— The Count then enquired whether I had any recent intelligence of the state of our affairs with England— I said I had received the Official Account of the American Captain, of the action between the two ships of which he had doubtless heard— I had not seen the Account of the English Captain— If it should give a statement materially different from the other in regard to the facts, I could not say what would be the consequence; but if the facts were as stated by Commodore Rogers, the British Government I supposed would disavow their officer’s conduct, as they have done in so many cases before— In the present case however there was the difference, that their ship and men had been the greatest sufferers— He said he had seen Accounts from England, with the Gazettes down to 28 June— That there appeared to be great agitation in the public mind there; on account of that Event, and it was said a Squadron commanded by an Admiral York had been ordered to sail for America.— But then it appeared the struggle in Spain was all to be gone over again— Very differently from what had been so lately expected— It had been thought that if the War in that Country was not entirely at an end, at least the English had obtained a decisive preponderancy— But now the French army under Marshal Soult was reinforced and concentrated, and Lord Wellington had been obliged to raise the Siege of Badajos, in order to draw all his forces together for another Battle— Now the Event of another general action was to be waited for— I said that from the late Speeches of the Emperor Napoleon, and of his Minister of the Interior, it appeared that France did not give up the game for lost in Spain— But that it remained to be seen whether the French armies there would be reinforced— He said that reinforcements had certainly been ordered— That troops had marched from Toulon and Marseilles, and he was informed by despatches from the Ambassador at Paris, Prince Kurakin, that after a review lately of several Regiments at Paris, by the Emperor Napoleon, they immediately received marching orders; and were gone to Spain— The Count told me that he had taken this place in the Country, in order to be near the Emperor; but he found it so inconvenient for the transmission to and fro, of all the papers, that must pass under his inspection, that he should give it up after next week— On returning home, I gave Mr: Hazard the papers I have received from Mr: Mumford and Mr: Wolcott of New-York, respecting the Fox, a vessel which they wish to get admitted at Archangel— I wrote and sent the Note to Count Romanzoff requesting an exequatur for Mr Hazard— After dinner we had a visit from Count Maistre— I walked round by the lower bridge, and up the opposite shore over the upper Bridges— When I got home I found the French Ambassador on a visit; and also Mr Fisher and Mr: Blodget—the former of whom brought us out an American flag, which he procured for us from Cronstadt.— We had it hoisted at the end of our wharf.— Mr Harris and Commodore Bainbridge were here while I was out.

26. I have this day been married fourteen years, during which I have to bless God, for the enjoyment of a portion of felicity resulting from this relation in Society, greater than falls to the generality of mankind, and far beyond any thing that I have been conscious of deserving— Its greatest alloy has arisen from the delicacy of my wife’s Constitution, the ill health which has afflicted her much of the time, and the misfortunes she has suffered from it— Our Union has not been without its trials; nor invariably without dissensions between us— There are many differences of Sentiment, of tastes and of opinions in regard to domestic economy, and to the education of children between us— There are natural frailties of temper in both of us; both being quick, and irascible, and mine being sometimes harsh— But she has always been a faithful and affectionate wife, and a careful, tender, indulgent and watchful mother to our children, all of whom she nursed herself— I have found in this Connection from decisive experience the superior happiness of the marriage state over that of celibacy, and a full conviction that my lot in marriage has been highly favoured— I completed this day a letter to my father which I have been nearly a week writing— The Chevalier Bezerra,
and his Lady, and Mr Navarro paid us visits this Evening— Madame Bezerra is to be presented to the Empress on Sunday, and to-morrow pays her visit to Countess Litta— Mrs Adams goes to introduce her.— I walked this Evening in the Apothecary’s or Botanical Garden, which is near a mile distant from my house, towards the Neva— But the rain obliged me to return before I had entirely explored it.

27. Mr: Montreal breakfasted with us— But having had no other interruption afterwards in the course of the morning, I was able to write an entire letter, which I have scarcely done before since we came upon the island— In the Evening I walked round the island upon which we reside in a different direction from any that I had before examined— Mr: and Madam Bezerra came, and Mrs Adams went with them to Count Litta’s— They reside on the opposite side of the river, on the Wiburg side, and within sight of us. My walk was again shortened by the rain.

28. Mr: Harris came this morning and introduced to me, an American Gentleman, a Mr. Parker from Perth Amboy.— We had to dine with us Messrs: Blodget, Fisher, Hall, Hazard, Hollins, Montreal, two Plummer’s Roberts, Thorndike, Willing and Woodward— I had invited also the two Messrs: Harris, Commodore Bainbridge, Captain Jones, and Mr Colhoun, but they were engaged— Mr: Harris informed me of Commodore Bainbridge’s desire to be presented at Court.— Mr Krabbe paid us an Evening visit— Madam Bezerra called on Mrs Adams, on her return from her presentation to the Empress— I took again a shorter walk than usual, our Company having stayed untill past ten— I read two of Massillon’s Synodial Discourses— On the gentleness—and the learning necessary for a Priest.

29. Dined with Mr Fisher, who had a Company of twenty Gentlemen, chiefly Americans, at dinner— He has a complete collection of the Russian medals—struck on thin plates of pewter— There are large ones, of about three inches diameter; and small ones about the size of half a dollar— They have the heads of all the Russian Sovereigns from the time of Rurik down to Paul— The inscriptions are all in the Russian language and characters— After dinner I went to the Chevalier Bezerra’s, and to see Mr Navarro, but neither of them was at home— I left for Mr: Navarro an American Newspaper mentioning the Clearance of a vessel from New-York, on board of which his two brothers had taken passage for Brezil. Seeing the name of Messrs: Navarro, among those of the sufferers, by a great fire at New-York in May, he has been very uneasy on their account. But probably the sufferers by the fire were other persons of the same name.— I walked home— Mr: Labouchere had been to visit us, and pass’d an hour with the Ladies—

30. I received two Notes from Count Romanzoff. One to inform me of the appointment of Mr: Daschkoff as Russian Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to the United States in the room of Count Pahlen, and the other to notify me that the Emperor had given orders that Mr: Hazard, should be immediately recognized as Consul at Archangel, and authorized to enter on the exercise of his functions— I answered one of these Notes, and left the other for to-morrow— The whole morning was engrossed by one of those occasional occupations which so often divert me from business of more urgency— I found in an American Newspaper, a return of the whole population of the United States, by the last Census of 1810. and I engaged myself in calculations, resulting from a comparison of it with the returns of 1790. and 1800. The proportion of increase between the second and third Census, is exactly the same as that between the first and second— It is between 36 and 37 per Cent in ten years; rather more than three per Cent, and very nearly 31 per 1000. annually.— I do not think it possible that this proportion should continue even for the next ten years— It is a phenomenon which the world never witnessed before, and which probably will never be seen again— The state in which we have been the last twenty years is too happy a Condition for human nature long to endure— Blessed be God for it; and may he still protract it, notwithstanding the ingratitude and other vices by which we have forfeited almost the right to ask his favour— May he also protract the portion of virtue in the people, which has hitherto contributed to preserve the blessings they have enjoyed. May he continue to build up a State, which shall exhibit a clear and permanent improvement in the existence of social man. When I reflect upon the capabilities of that people, and that Territory, I have no curb to enthusiastic hope, but in the recollection of the follies and vices which have proved so fatal to mankind in all former ages, and which threaten to destroy all the glorious prospects of my Country— Let me implore the aid of Heaven to meditate further, and to some useful purpose on this subject. so that this may not be a day lost.— I walked over the Bridge’s and Kammenoi Ostroff to the opposite Bank of the river— On my return I found Mr: Harris on a visit to us— My wife was quite unwell this morning, and I was not altogether well myself— Anxious more than sick.

31. Mr: Montreal breakfasted with us. He brought me a minute of a new draft on Messrs: Bainbridge and Brown, on account of Mr Gray. I had much Conversation with him respecting the transaction of business. I have constant reason to see the necessity of attention to his interests— Mr Montreal now thinks it highly important for Mr: Gray’s interest that all his business should be done by one house— When Mr Meyer thought so last Autumn, to exclude Mr Montreal’s house from a participation of the business Mr: Montreal was of a very different opinion. It is perhaps unreasonable to expect that men’s minds should not be swayed by their interests.— I answered Count Romanzoff’s second note and sent them both.— I wrote also to Mr: Hazard— Mr: Fisher and Mr. David were here, an hour or two in the Evening.

Day. It was on the first of this month that I received notice to quit the house in which we had resided, within a fortnight; I left it accordingly, and removed to our present residence on the Apothecary’s island, next door to the surgical school, on the banks of the Great Nevka, but within the limits of the City— I have before remarked that a removal always produces some disorder in the course of my daily occupations. This effect has been now increased by the multitudes of American vessels, newspapers, letters, and visitors arrived in the course of the month Scarcely a day passes without visitors—seldom without bringing them both morning and Evening— My health has suffered, and anxieties of various kinds have contributed to absorb my time. I believe I have written less this month than any Month since I landed at St: Petersburg— Yet I seem to have been quite as constantly employed— My hours of breakfast and dining have been ten A.M. and 5. P.M. as heretofore. Those of going to bed and rising as irregular— My leisure for such meditations as I would gladly pursue, none— I despair of having a better account of myself the next Month
